10.

11.

12.

13.

completion of the County beltway. A decision not to continue with
an expressway program clearly focused on the downtown area would
jeopardize the many efforts now being made to save the central
business district.

Failure to prepare and carry out adequate plans for the handling of
future traffic increases would have pronounced effects upon the struc-
ture and character of the City. It seems probable that such a failure
would result in increased congestion, reduced mobility, less freedom
to select jobs or home sites, a speed-up in decentralization, a greater
dispersion of many functions throughout the metropolitan area, a
lower level of cultural activities and of specialized services and busi-
nesses, and a reduced rate of economic growth.

Any route for an East-West Expressway should satisfy the following

minimum requirements:

a. It should be planned in such a way that it will be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System and thus be
eligible for 909 Federal grant.

b. A feasible interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway must be
possible.

c. It should provide good service to the central business district.

In judging between routes meeting the above requirements the fol-
lowing criteria are important: benefits to traffic, to the central
business district, and to the City’s economy; stimulus to new building
or to urban renewal; possible blighting effects; number and quality
of dwellings to be demolished; effect on assessed valuations; total
cost; and significant or important properties to be taken.

No small-scale improvements can be made in the present alignment
of the Northern Route.





14.

15.

16.

1.

Only one largely new route for the East-West Expressway was dis-
covered which met all of the requirements set forth in Item 11 above.
This route is referred to as the Harbor Route. It is shown in its
entirety on Sheet 7 and in detail on Sheets 8 through 12 and 23
through 28. From the western City line to Myrtle Avenue the Harbor
Route is identical to the Northern Route. After crossing Myrtle
Avenue the Harbor Route turns due south to Pratt Street, then turns
east between Pratt and Camden Streets, crosses the Municipal Piers
just south of Pratt Street, crosses under the Jones Falls Expressway
at about Pier 6, then follows approximately along the north side of
the Harbor to Boston Street. It continues on Boston Street until it
joins the Harbor Tunnel entrance road. It is proposed that the
Harbor Tunnel entrance road be widened to the point where it merges
with the proposed new Northeastern Expressway.

A desirable feature of many past expressway plans has been an inner
ring around the central business district. This inner ring could also
be provided using the Harbor Route by means of an expressway
connection running from the Harbor Route at about Myrtle Avenue
northeasterly to the Jones Falls Expressway.

Transfer of the East-West Expressway from the Northern Route to
the Harbor Route would permit a partial expressway connection
between the Jones Falls Expressway at about Eager Street and the
northeastern section of the City.

A comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route in
terms of the criteria set forth in Item 12 above indicates that the
Harbor Route is superior with respect to the following items:

a. Conformity to desire lines

b. Relief for present congestion

c. Opportunities for related traffic improvements

.
